newsitem.title: JAPAN: JAPAN TRADE SURPLUS FALLS IN JAN BUT RISES VS U.S..
newsitem.headline: JAPAN TRADE SURPLUS FALLS IN JAN BUT RISES VS U.S..

text.p: Japan`s customs-cleared trade surplus fell sharply in January, plunging 91.7 percent from a year earlier to 5.19 billion yen (41.8 million), but the drop was a seasonal one, the Ministry of Finance said on Wednesday.
The closely watched trade surplus with the United States, often a source of trade friction, rose 81.6 percent in January from a year earlier to 298.34 billion yen (2.40 billion).
The growth in the surplus with the United States was mainly due to higher sales of cars, a ministry official said.
This jump was offset, however, by Japan`s trade with China, which was in deficit by 291.42 billion yen (2.35 billion).

The drop in the January overall surplus, the 26th consecutive month of year-on-year declines, was due to traditional sluggishness in productivity during the New Year holiday period, the ministry official said.
Seasonally adjusted, the customs-cleared trade surplus was up 25.6 percent.
Economists had been deeply divided in their forecasts for the figures due to seasonal factors and they said January figures are a poor guide to changes in Japan`s trade patterns.

"If you look at the seasonally adjusted figures, it`s pretty clear that the bottom was around last May, so it has been gradually trending up," said Peter Morgan, chief economist at James Capel Pacific. "It`s really a question of at what point you will see a year-on-year rise, certainly by the second quarter."
Many economists said they expect the yen`s fall since mid-1995 to boost exports while discouraging imports, eventually causing a halt in the trend of a declining surplus.
A weaker yen makes Japanese products cheaper in terms of foreign currency.

"The reason why both imports and exports are so strong in value terms is that the value of the yen has depreciated," said Jason James, a strategist at James Capel. "The underlying trend is for exports picking up more strongly now than imports. We have been seeing the seasonally adjusted surplus pick up, and I think this will definitely continue this year."
Overall exports in January grew 17.2 percent from a year earlier in yen value terms, which was the biggest growth since July 1996, when they grew 17.5 percent, the official said.

Exports to the United States in January rose 26.5 percent year-on-year to 1.055 trillion yen (8.5 billion). A rise in imports from the United States of 13.0 percent to 756.87 billion yen (6.10 billion) was mainly due to imports of aircraft and audiovisual equipment, he said.
